I.  THE PROPOSAL 
 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan to 
the Republic of the Union of Myanmar for the additional financing of the Greater Mekong 
Subregion Health Security Project.1  
 
2.  The original project is helping Cambodia, the Lao People’s Democratic Republic (Lao 
PDR), Myanmar, and Viet Nam comply with the International Health Regulations (IHR) and the 
requirement to develop core health system capacities to respond to public health threats of 
national  and  international  concern.2 Project  investments  support  three  outputs:  (i) regional 
cooperation and communicable disease control in border areas improved, (ii) national disease 
surveillance  and  outbreak  response  system  strengthened,  and  (iii)  laboratory  services  and 
hospital infection prevention and control (IPC) improved. In Myanmar, the original project is being 
implemented  with  the  National  Health  Laboratory  and  in  13  state,  regional,  and  township 
hospitals. The proposed additional financing will support implementation of the government’s 
Health Sector Contingency Plan (HSCP) for coronavirus disease (COVID-19).3 The additional 
financing  will  provide  targeted  investment  for  31  district  and  township  hospitals  requiring 
immediate upgrading of clinical care, IPC, and human resource capacity to respond to COVID-19 
and other future public health threats.4 The additional financing will complement ADB’s support 
under  the  COVID-19  Active  Response  and  Expenditure  Support  (CARES)  Program.5 The 
additional financing project remains aligned with the outcome of the original project: Greater 
Mekong Subregion (GMS) health system performance with regard to health security improved. 
The report and recommendation of the President for the original project is accessible from the list 
of linked documents in Appendix 2. 
 
II.  THE PROJECT 
 
A.  Rationale 
 
3.  The Asian Development Bank (ADB) approved the original project on 22 November 2016, 
for a total of $125 million equivalent to Cambodia, the Lao PDR, Myanmar, and Viet Nam (footnote 
1). On 22 May 2020, additional financing of $20 million was approved for the Lao PDR to support 
a new project output for emergency response to the COVID-19 outbreak (footnote 1). The project

[$4 million]), Myanmar ($12 million), and Viet Nam (SDR56,946,000 [$80 million]); and (ii) a grant to the Lao PDR 
($8 million). ADB provided a loan (additional financing) to the Lao PDR ($20 million). ADB also provided project 
preparatory technical assistance of $1.3 million to Cambodia, the Lao PDR, Myanmar, and Viet Nam. ADB. Greater

2 
completion date is 31 March 2022, and the loan closing date is 30 September 2022. As of 2 
September 2020, against the elapsed project time of 65.0%, implementation of the original project 
in Myanmar was on track. Cumulative contract awards for Myanmar are $3.7 million (31.1% of 
ADB financing) and disbursements $4.6 million (38.8%, including advances of $1.3 million). Of 
the 10 outcome and output indicators for Myanmar, 5 have already been achieved, 4 are partially 
achieved, and 1 has yet to start. The delivery of expected outputs is rated successful. Project 
covenants, including all safeguard covenants, are either complied with or are being complied with. 
The identified project implementation risks have been adequately mitigated and the management 
of risks is rated successful.  
 
4.  The Government of Myanmar has requested $30 million for the proposed additional 
financing to strengthen preparedness and response capacity of the health system for COVID-19.6 
As of 18 September 2020, Myanmar reported 4,299 confirmed cases of COVID-19, with 68 
deaths.7 Of the confirmed cases, 3,995 are linked to local transmission, with clusters in Rakhine 
State, Yangon and Mandalay.8 Myanmar remains highly vulnerable to a surge in case numbers. 
The country’s high number of returning migrants from the People’s Republic of China, Thailand, 
and other neighboring countries, increases the risk for imported COVID-19 cases.9 Poor and 
crowded living conditions in urban and peri-urban areas, with inadequate water and sanitation 
infrastructure, create the conditions for local transmission and the potential for spread of COVID-
19 in the country. The high prevalence of communicable and chronic illnesses that compromise 
immune and respiratory system functioning increases the risk of comorbidity and more severe 
clinical progression of COVID-19.10 While the Ministry of Health and Sports (MOHS) has scaled 
up the country’s testing capacity, the number of tests performed remains the lowest in Southeast 
Asia at 3,906 per million population.11 
 
5.  The MOHS and the World Health Organization (WHO) assess Myanmar’s preparedness 
capacity for responding to COVID-19 at less than 60%, with the greatest weakness at the 
subnational level.12 Investment is needed immediately in district and township hospitals,13 which 
are pivotal in the assessment, isolation, and treatment of COVID-19 cases, particularly in remote 
and border areas (footnote 3). District and township hospitals face constraints in three key areas: 
(i) emergency departments and clinical wards lack facilities for separation of infectious patients 
as well as equipment for diagnosis and clinical management of severe respiratory diseases and 
comorbidities; (ii) systems for IPC and the management of infectious medical waste are weak and 
supplies of personal protective equipment (PPE) inadequate, increasing the risk of COVID-19 
among health sector staff, patients, and the community; and (iii) health staff, 75% of whom are

female, lack the requisite knowledge for assessment and clinical management of COVID-19, IPC, 
and psychosocial care for patients.14 Strengthening capacity of medical care services, IPC, and 
human resources in district and township hospitals is prioritized under the HSCP.15  
 
6.  The proposed additional financing to the health security project is an efficient modality for 
the expedited delivery of support to district and township hospitals under MOHS’s COVID-19 
response (footnote 3). The approach leverages the experience of MOHS with ADB project 
administration and its capacity to deliver activities with township and district hospitals. Channeling 
support as additional financing to the health security project ensures synergies between targeted 
investment to combat COVID-19 and ongoing efforts to strengthen preparedness and capacity to 
respond to public health threats. The proposed additional financing has been determined to be 
technically feasible, economically viable, and financially sound. The project meets the criteria for 
COVID-19 fast-track processing.16 
 
7.  The project is aligned with the government’s strong commitment to regional health security 
and achievement of the IHR core capacities (footnote 2). The project is consistent with the ADB 
Strategy  2030’s  operational  priorities  (OPs)  to  (i)  address  remaining  poverty  and  reduce 
inequalities by achieving better health for all (OP1); (ii) accelerate progress in gender equality in 
human development (OP2); and (iii) foster regional cooperation and integration, including the 
promotion of regional public goods to mitigate cross-border risks of communicable disease 
(OP7).17 The project remains aligned with ADB’s country partnership strategy for Myanmar, 2017–
2021,  which  prioritizes  advancing  regional  public  health  to  reduce  constraints  to  inclusive 
development.18 The project contributes to the collective goal of the GMS countries to improve the 
GMS health system response to acute public health threats.19 
 
B.  Project Description 
 
8.  The  project  is  aligned  with  the  following  impact:  GMS  public  health  security 
strengthened.20 The project will have the following outcome: GMS health system performance 
with  regard  to  health  security  improved.21The  impact  and  outcome  of  the  project  remain 
unchanged from the original project. The additional financing will help Myanmar comply with the 
requirements of the IHR and WHO’s Asia Pacific Strategy for Emerging Diseases, in line with the 
original project outcome indicators.22 The project expands the scope of the original project to 
encompass investment to strengthen preparedness for responding to COVID-19 in 31 district and

township hospitals (para. 2). Target hospitals are in areas that are highly vulnerable because of 
poverty, ethnicity, and inadequate access to essential services, including health care.23  
 
9.  Activities under the additional financing will be consolidated and delivered through output 
4, which is aligned with and contributes to the original project outcome. Output 4 will be rephrased 
as “emergency preparedness and response capacity for COVID-19 strengthened,” which will fully 
capture the objectives of the additional financing. In line with the HSCP, activities under output 4 
will strengthen capacity across three core areas of district and township hospital service delivery 
(para. 5): (i) clinical management and medical care services, (ii) IPC at the project hospitals, and 
(iii) human resources. 
 
10.  Clinical management and medical care services. Emergency departments, isolation 
wards, hospital laboratories, and medical and high-dependency care units will be provided with 
equipment to support the assessment, isolation, and treatment of patients with COVID-19 and 
associated comorbidities. Small-scale refurbishment works will be carried out to enable the 
installation and operation of hospital equipment, including equipment to supply oxygen, electricity, 
water, and other essential inputs. The mix of equipment and scope of works for each hospital will 
be determined through individual assessments. 
 
11.  Hospital infection prevention and control. Small-scale works will prepare hospital 
wards for the separation and isolation of infectious patients and provide separate facilities for 
female and male patients and staff members. Autoclaves, microwave incinerators, and liquid 
waste treatment tanks will be installed in selected hospitals, improving their management of solid 
and liquid infectious waste. The PPE, in appropriate sizes, will be provided for female and male 
hospital staff members. 
 
12.  Human resources. Female and male hospital staff members will receive training on 
assessment of patients with respiratory infections, IPC, laboratory, and clinical management for 
COVID-19 and associated comorbidities. Female and male hospital staff members will receive 
training on the detection of gender-based violence (GBV) and associated referral options through 
an ongoing regional technical assistance project.24 
 
C.  Value Added by ADB  
 
13.  Since  ADB  reengaged  with  Myanmar  in  2012,  its  health  sector  investments  have 
supported health security initiatives linked to regional cooperation and integration (footnote 1) and 
HIV prevention.25 These investments, which focus on strengthening core public health system 
capacities, particularly in cross-border areas, build on ADB’s value addition as a trusted partner 
in regional health cooperation in the GMS. Achievements from this engagement highlight ADB’s 
comparative advantage in delivering targeted support at the regional, township and community 
levels. ADB has leveraged this advantage in its support to the government’s response to COVID-
19. Initial reprogramming of $6.6 million under the ongoing health security project will address  
immediate  subnational  needs  for  laboratory  diagnostics,  emergency  care  equipment,  and 
consumables. The proposed additional financing project will complement this investment by 
extending support for the COVID-19 response to additional district and township hospitals. 
Recognizing that resources are limited, ADB is coordinating closely with other development

partners through the MOHS-led health cluster coordination mechanism to ensure alignment of 
COVID-19 support. The World Bank will provide a $50 million loan and $8 million grant under the 
Myanmar COVID-19 Emergency Response Project, which will support investment for 61 state, 
and district hospitals in locations not supported by the proposed ADB additional financing.26  
 
14.  ADB synergizes investments in the health sector to maximize cumulative impacts. The 
additional financing project will complement ADB’s CARES Program to Myanmar, which supports 
implementation  of  the  government’s  COVID-19  Economic  Relief  Plan  (CERP),  including 
investment to strengthen health systems. 27  The additional financing is aligned with ongoing 
assistance to the MOHS under ADB’s regional technical assistance (TA) projects.28 Under ADB’s 
wider health sector portfolio, the proposed Improving Noncommunicable Diseases Prevention 
and Treatment Project will enhance capacity of prevention and treatment services for non-
communicable diseases.29 Recognizing ADB’s synergistic approach as a comparative advantage, 
the government has requested ADB for TA to (i) undertake a diagnostic study of health sector 
systems for public financial management to determine the required reforms and the sustainability 
of health sector investments; and (ii) prepare a national hospital plan to guide medium-term 
investment in hospital development across the country.30  
 
15.  ADB applies a conflict-sensitive approach to all its operations in Myanmar.31  Conflict-
sensitive design features of the project include (i) strengthening project management unit (PMU) 
staff  and  consultants’  understanding  of  ethnic  and  cultural  differences  in  a  post-conflict 
environment through training on conflict sensitivity, (ii) ensuring that information about the project 
and  its  benefits  is  translated  into  local  languages  and  accessible  to  all  communities, 
(iii) implementing an ethnic group development plan to maximize the project’s positive benefits 
for all ethnic communities, (iv) ensuring that the most vulnerable populations have access to 
critical health services through coordination between the MOHS and civil society organizations 
and  ethnic  health  organizations,  and  (v)  periodically  reviewing  project  implementation  to 
determine additional mitigation measures that may be required.  
 
D.  Summary Cost Estimates and Financing Plan

including  taxes  and  duties,  physical  and  price  contingencies,  and  interest  charges  during 
implementation. In Myanmar, the original project is estimated to cost $12.8 million and the 
additional financing project $32.2 million. Detailed cost estimates by expenditure category and by 
financier are included in the project administration manual (PAM).32

E.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
19.  As in the original project, the MOHS, through its Department of Medical Services (DOMS), 
will be the executing agency for the additional financing. The director general of the DOMS will 
be the project director. A new PMU will be established under the DOMS to support the project 
director in management, monitoring, and administration of the additional financing.33 The PMU 
will be supported by 10 national consultants. The 31 district and township hospitals will act as 
implementing agencies. The medical superintendents of each hospital will oversee the planning 
and implementation of project activities in their facilities.

III.  DUE DILIGENCE 
 
A.  Technical 
 
22.  Based on its guidelines on the essential equipment required by district and township 
hospitals to respond to COVID-19, the MOHS, in close collaboration with the target hospitals, has 
selected the equipment to be provided. These guidelines were developed in consultation with the 
WHO and are aligned with WHO’s global guidelines. Detailed engineering assessments will be 
undertaken for each hospital to ensure that the requisite conditions and services are in place for 
optimum functioning of the equipment. The goods contracts for the installation of the medical 
equipment will include provisions for training hospital staff members on the use of equipment 
procured under the project. The purchase of goods will prioritize those for which local agents are 
present in Myanmar or elsewhere in the region, to facilitate after-sales services relating to spare 
parts, consumables provision, and associated support.  
 
B.  Economic and Financial Viability 
 
23.  The economic analysis was updated following 2017 ADB's Guidelines on Economic 
Analysis (2017).34 The cost-effectiveness analysis conducted for the additional financing shows 
that the cost per disability-adjusted life year is less than three times the gross domestic product  
per  capita, making the  intervention  very  cost-effective.35 The  results are  robust  to  various 
sensitivity scenarios. The cost–benefit analysis conducted for the original project was also 
updated. An economic internal rate of return of 28.1% was estimated for the additional financing, 
higher than the economic internal rate of return of the original project of 23.4% and above the 
minimum required threshold of 6.0% for social sector investments.36 
 
C.  Sustainability 
24.  The financial analysis confirmed that the government has adequate budgetary resources 
to absorb any incremental recurrent costs arising from the additional financing project. The annual 
incremental cost as a percentage of the government’s total health sector budget ranges from 
0.07% in FY2021 to 0.05% in FY2025. Although the economy grew at 6.8% in FY2019, ADB’s 
estimation of the gross domestic product growth rate for FY2020 has been reduced to 1.8%,

reflecting the adverse economic impact of COVID-19 within and outside of the country.37 The 
impact of COVID-19 will increase government spending on the health sector in the medium term. 
The government is implementing its CERP, amounting to $2.5 billion in FY2020 and FY2021 
(footnote 27). The CERP comprises a mix of health, social, and economic measures, and will help 
strengthen  the  health  care  system  and  increase  access  to  COVID-19  financing,  including 
contingency  funds.  The  additional  financing  project  is  likely  to  be  sustainable  with  the 
government’s strong commitment to supporting the health sector. 
 
D.  Governance 
 
25.  The government continues to strengthen its public financial management (PFM) with 
support from development partners by reforming the PFM system to improve governance and 
transparency.38 The first phase of the PFM system reform focused on (i) revenue and customs 
and budget planning, execution, and reporting at the Ministry of Planning Finance and Investment; 
(ii) support for the Office of the Auditor General; and (iii) the establishment of the PFM Academy 
to support government capacity building. The budget process has been improved significantly 
with the introduction of the Medium-Term Fiscal Framework. The PFM Academy provides training 
courses for line ministries, developed with support from development partners, including the 
International Monetary Fund (IMF).39 The government started the second phase (2018–2022) of 
its PFM reform strategy with various strengthening activities, including improving procurement 
law, internal audit capacity, and financial reporting systems.  
 
26.  The project pre-mitigation financial management and procurement risks are substantial. 
The additional financing will be implemented by the MOHS through the DOMS. The capacity of 
the MOHS and the DOMS remains constrained, particularly given the complexity of the supply 
market for medical goods. Limited capacity in procurement and financial management might 
impede emergency response activities. To mitigate these risks, UNOPS will be engaged to 
provide procurement and related services, including for minor civil works. ADB will support the 
MOHS  in  the  recruitment  of  individual  consultants.  A  separate  advance  account  will  be 
established at the MOHS through the DOMS. ADB will disburse a substantial portion of the loan 
through direct payment arrangements to UNOPS. The Office of the Auditor General will conduct 
the external audit of additional financing activities as part of the annual audit process for the 
overall project. With the mitigation measures, the financial management and procurement risk 
rating is moderate. 
 
27.  ADB’s Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended to date) was explained to and discussed 
with  the  government  and  the  MOHS.  The  specific  policy  requirements  and  supplementary 
measures are described in the PAM (footnote 32). 
 
E.  Poverty, Social, and Gender 
 
28.  Poverty. The additional financing project is classified as a general intervention. The 
project supports poverty reduction indirectly through investments to strengthen the capacity of 
health services to respond to and mitigate the impacts of COVID-19. Households are at high risk 
of  being  significantly  burdened  financially  by  COVID-19–related  illness.  Global  evidence 
 
37 ADB. 2020. Asian Development Outlook 2020 Supplement. Manila. The initial projected economic growth for 
Myanmar was 4.2% for FY2020, returning to 6.8% or to pre-COVID-19 levels in FY2021. ADB. 2020. Asian 
Development Outlook 2020 April 2020. Manila.

Myanmar.

10 
illustrates that the social and economic burden from pandemics falls disproportionately on poor 
and marginalized groups.40 In Myanmar, out-of-pocket payments constituted 72.6% of total health 
expenditure in 2017.41 About 16.0% of Myanmar households face catastrophic health spending, 
and 3.4% of the population is pushed into poverty each year because of health spending.42 
Ensuring that health services have the capacity to mitigate the health impacts of COVID-19 
contributes to an enabling environment for pro-poor growth.  
 
29.  Social. The additional financing project will decrease communicable diseases. It will 
directly lower the risk of COVID-19 spread by strengthening hospital capacity to diagnose, isolate, 
and treat COVID-19 patients. These interventions will improve hospital capacity to respond to 
emerging disease threats. The MOHS, through its direct contract with UNOPS, will ensure that all 
works contracts comply with national labor laws and do not involve (i) forced labor, (ii) child labor, 
and (iii) discrimination in the workplace. 
 
30.  Gender. The additional financing is categorized as effective gender mainstreaming. The 
gender action plan (GAP) for the original project has been updated to incorporate gender targets 
and actions for output 4. Myanmar’s health workforce is highly feminized (75%): almost all nursing 
professionals and more than half of medical practitioners are female.43 However, a high proportion 
of female health workers are concentrated in lower-level technical and managerial positions. 
COVID-19 exacerbate social issues linked to gender inequality, particularly the incidence of GBV. 
The gender and social dimensions of the project are largely concerned with ensuring that (i) 
facilities in the targeted hospitals guarantee appropriate privacy for female patients and staff 
members; (ii) female and male health workers have equal opportunity to participate in trainings 
on COVID-19 clinical management, IPC, laboratory techniques; (iii) female and male health 
workers have access to appropriately sized PPE; and (iv) female and male health workers have 
the required knowledge and skills to provide support and referral options to persons affected by 
GBV. The PMU, with the support of a national gender specialist, will monitor GAP implementation. 
A knowledge, attitude, and perception survey will track improvements in health workers’ response 
to GBV. Progress on GAP implementation will be included in all progress and monitoring and 
evaluation reports. Project data will be disaggregated by sex to the extent possible.  
 
F.  Safeguards 
 
31.  In compliance with ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement (2009), the project’s safeguard 
categories are as follows.44  
 
32.  Environment (category C). The additional financing will not involve any major civil works 
or activities in environmentally sensitive areas. Each implementing agency will assign one 
qualified staff member to monitor and oversee minor renovation works and to establish COVID-
19 risk management protocols for contractors and equipment suppliers. A national safeguard 
specialist will support the PMU and the implementing agencies in setting up environment, health, 
and safety protocols, and will support the PMU in submitting quarterly project progress reports on 
the project’s performance in environmental health and safety. The original project remains 
category B for environment and the environmental management plan will continue to apply.

V. RECOMMENDATION
38. I am satisfied that the proposed loan would comply with the Articles of Agreement of the
Asian Development Bank (ADB) and recommend that the Board approve the loan of $30,000,000
to the Republic of the Union of Myanmar for the additional financing of the Greater Mekong
Subregion Health Security Project, from ADB’s ordinary capital resources, in concessional terms,
with an interest charge at the rate of 1.0% per year during the grace period and 1.5% per year
thereafter; for a term of 32 years, including a grace period of 8 years; and such other terms and
conditions as are substantially in accordance with those set forth in the draft loan agreement
presented to the Board.

metadata.Subject: The additional financing will support implementation of the government’s Health Sector Contingency Plan (HSCP) for coronavirus disease (COVID-19). It will provide targeted investment for 31 district and township hospitals requiring immediate upgrading of clinical care, infection prevention and control, and human resource capacity to respond to COVID-19 and other future public health threats. It will complement ADB’s support under the COVID-19 Active Response and Expenditure Support Program. The additional financing project remains aligned with the outcome of the original project: Greater Mekong Subregion health system performance with regard to health security improved.
